title: Conserving our spectacular, vulnerable coral reefs - Joshua Drew

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of marine conservation biologists in protecting coral reefs?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a single large protected area for each reef system

options.label: B
options.text: To balance the need for conservation with the needs of people who rely on reefs for survival

options.label: C
options.text: To study the genetics and DNA of fish in coral reefs

options.label: D
options.text: To create a system of protected areas that excludes people from traditional fishing grounds

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "connectivity" in the context of marine conservation?

options.label: A
options.text: Creating a single large protected area for each reef system

options.label: B
options.text: Creating a system of protected areas that are not connected to each other

options.label: C
options.text: Creating a system of protected areas that are nested together like pearls on a string

options.label: D
options.text: Studying the genetics and DNA of fish in coral reefs

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the benefits of creating a system of connected protected areas?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for the exclusion of people from traditional fishing grounds

options.label: B
options.text: It provides insurance against events such as oil spills or coral bleaching

options.label: C
options.text: It only protects coral reefs and not other marine habitats

options.label: D
options.text: It does not allow for the sharing of costs and benefits among communities

multiple-choice.question: What is another benefit of creating a system of connected protected areas?

options.label: A
options.text: It only protects coral reefs and not other marine habitats

options.label: B
options.text: It allows for the exclusion of people from traditional fishing grounds

options.label: C
options.text: It provides representation of different marine habitats

options.label: D
options.text: It does not allow for the sharing of costs and benefits among communities

multiple-choice.question: How do scientists determine if the protected areas are connected and self-sustaining?

options.label: A
options.text: By studying the genetics and DNA of fish in each reserve

options.label: B
options.text: By creating a single large protected area for each reef system

options.label: C
options.text: By excluding people from traditional fishing grounds

options.label: D
options.text: By only protecting coral reefs and not other marine habitats

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to study a variety of different species in the protected areas?

options.label: A
options.text: Because what is happening with one species is guaranteed to be happening with all species

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is only necessary to study one species to understand the entire ecosystem

options.label: C
options.text: Because there is no guarantee that what is happening with one species is happening with all species

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is not important to understand the entire ecosystem

multiple-choice.question: What have scientists found regarding the connectivity of protected areas in Fiji?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no connectivity among the parks within Fiji

options.label: B
options.text: There is a fair amount of connectivity among the parks within Fiji, but it's not a big free-for-all

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The parks within Fiji are only connected for certain species

multiple-choice.question: What is a challenge that scientists have found regarding the connectivity of protected areas in Fiji?

options.label: A
options.text: Babies born in the far west are having an easy time making it to the islands in the far east

options.label: B
options.text: Babies born in the far west are having a hard time making it to the islands in the far east

options.label: C
options.text: There is no challenge regarding the connectivity of protected areas in Fiji

options.label: D
options.text: The parks within Fiji are not connected and are not self-sustaining

multiple-choice.question: What is a suggestion that conservation biologists have made to address the challenge of connectivity in Fiji?

options.label: A
options.text: Create a single large protected area for each reef system

options.label: B
options.text: Create more parks in the east and west to keep populations healthy

options.label: C
options.text: Exclude people from traditional fishing grounds

options.label: D
options.text: Only protect coral reefs and not other marine habitats

options.label: C
options.text: Only in the South Pacific Ocean

options.label: D

title: Inside a cartoonist’s world - Liza Donnelly

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why cartoons have survived as an art form for so long?

options.label: B
options.text: They elicit a wide range of emotions and can transmit ideas instantly.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only enjoyed by children.

options.label: D
options.text: They are limited to a specific medium.

multiple-choice.question: Where do cartoonists often get their ideas from?

options.label: C
options.text: A variety of places, including observing life, reading newspapers, and online sources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of a cartoonist in creating a cartoon?

options.label: C
options.text: As a playwright, director, stage designer, choreographer, and costume designer.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the characters in a cartoon?

options.label: A
options.text: To distract from the main idea.

options.label: B
options.text: To dress in a way that is unnatural and confusing.

options.label: C
options.text: To dress in a way that fits the idea and speak in a way that forwards the idea or gives the punchline.

multiple-choice.question: How do some cartoonists add gray tone to their cartoons?

options.label: B
options.text: By using black watercolor and a brush.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the image and words in a cartoon?

options.label: B
options.text: To dance together in a way that makes sense.

options.label: C
options.text: To have no relation to each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final stage of creating a cartoon?

options.label: C
options.text: Scanning and adjusting the cartoon, and adding the caption on the computer.

options.label: D
options.text: Drawing directly on the paper in pen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of new technologies in creating cartoons?

options.label: B
options.text: To serve as a tool for color and image, and to provide new options for creation.

options.label: C
options.text: To limit the creativity of cartoonists.

options.label: D
options.text: To have no impact on the creation process.

options.label: A
options.text: A confusing and disjointed work of art.

options.label: B
options.text: A timeless and resilient work of art.

options.label: C
options.text: A work of art that is only appreciated by a few people.

options.label: D
options.text: A work of art that is only relevant for a short time.

multiple-choice.question: Why do cartoonists often carry a little black book with them?

options.label: A
options.text: To jot down ideas and observations.

options.text: That understanding the mathematical properties of shapes can help us understand real-world phenomena

options.label: D
options.text: That pizza slices are the only shapes that can be folded

title: How do cancer cells behave differently from healthy ones? - George Zaidan

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which a single cell divides to form 100 trillion cells in the human body?
What happens to a cell when its DNA gets a typo, also known as a mutation?

options.label: B
options.text: The cell senses the mistake and shuts itself down

options.label: C
options.text: The cell continues to divide normally

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of a cell's incorrect instructions being passed along to its offspring?

options.label: C
options.text: The cell continues to divide recklessly

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the type of cancer that is inherently everywhere in the body?
How do radiation and most forms of chemotherapy work to treat cancer?

options.label: B
options.text: By physically shredding the cells' DNA or disrupting the copying machinery

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of chemotherapy on healthy cells that divide frequently, such as hair cells?

options.label: C
options.text: They are killed by the chemotherapy

multiple-choice.question: Why do cancer treatments often have unpleasant side effects such as hair loss, skin rashes, and nausea?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the treatments are not effective

options.label: B
options.text: Because the treatments target only cancer cells

options.label: C
options.text: Because the treatments affect frequently dividing cells in the body

options.label: D
options.text: Because the treatments are too strong

multiple-choice.question: What is the main strength of cancer cells that is turned into a weakness by chemotherapy?

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to divide rapidly and recklessly

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to evade the immune system

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of cancer treatment, in terms of cell growth?
What is the relationship between cell division and the effectiveness of chemotherapy?

options.label: A
options.text: Cells that divide slowly are more susceptible to chemotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Cells that divide frequently are more susceptible to chemotherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Cells that divide normally are not affected by chemotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Cells that divide rapidly are resistant to chemotherapy

title: Let's talk about sex - John Bohannon and Black Label Movement

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of high school seniors had tried marijuana in the 1980s?
What was the name of the campaign led by Nancy Reagan to combat the use of drugs among young people?
According to the transcript, what was the outcome of the "war on sex" and the push for abstinence among young people to fight AIDS?
What is the author's argument about how to effectively communicate with children about sensitive topics such as sex and drugs?

options.label: A
options.text: To outsource the conversation to experts

options.label: B
options.text: To use scare tactics to deter them

options.label: C
options.text: To talk openly and honestly with them

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the author's view on childhood and how children learn about their bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: Childhood is a time of innocence and purity

options.label: B
options.text: Children learn about their bodies through formal education

options.label: C
options.text: Childhood is a time of curiosity and exploration, including about one's body

options.label: D
options.text: Children are not interested in learning about their bodies

multiple-choice.question: At what age did the author experience a particularly difficult time in their life, marked by obsessive curiosity about sex and deep shame?
According to the transcript, what is the author's message to their 13-year-old self about sex?

options.label: A
options.text: Sex is something to be ashamed of

options.label: C
options.text: Sex is a beautiful puzzle and not something to be embarrassed about

multiple-choice.question: What is the scientific theory mentioned in the transcript as a possible explanation for why sex evolved and persists?

options.label: C
options.text: Children who are genetically different from each other are protected from disease

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is unique about the way that humans reproduce compared to other forms of life?

options.label: B
options.text: Humans reproduce through a process called budding

options.label: C
options.text: Humans reproduce through sex, which involves the combination of genetic material from two parents

options.label: D
options.text: Humans reproduce through a process called fragmentation

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's final message to their 13-year-old self at the end of the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Be careful and avoid taking risks

options.label: B
options.text: Be nice to your little sister, she's your best friend

options.label: C
options.text: Focus on your studies and forget about sex

options.label: D
options.text: Don't trust anyone and only rely on yourself

title: Where do good ideas come from?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of critical thinking?

Which type of thinking involves generating new ideas and solutions?

Which cognitive bias involves relying too heavily on the first piece of information encountered when making a decision?
What is the name of the thinking strategy that involves identifying and challenging assumptions?
Which type of thinking involves applying learned knowledge to new situations?

title: How does work...work? - Peter Bohacek

multiple-choice.question: What is the unit of measurement for work and energy in the metric system?
What type of energy is stored in the grandfather clock when the metal cylinders are raised?
How is the amount of work done calculated?

options.label: A
options.text: By multiplying the force applied times the distance over which the force is applied

options.label: B
options.text: By dividing the force applied by the distance over which the force is applied

options.label: C
options.text: By adding the force applied and the distance over which the force is applied

options.label: D
options.text: By subtracting the force applied from the distance over which the force is applied

multiple-choice.question: What is the unit of measurement for power in the metric system?
Who is the term Watt named after?
What is the rate at which energy is transferred called?
How much power is required to run a bright, 100-Watt light bulb compared to the power required to run the grandfather clock?
What happens to the energy stored in the grandfather clock when the cylinders move downward?

options.label: D
options.text: It is converted to a different type of energy

multiple-choice.question: How long does it take for the cylinders to return to their original position in the grandfather clock?
Approximately how many clocks could be run using the same power it takes to run one 100-Watt light bulb?

title: Dance vs. PowerPoint, a modest proposal - John Bohannon and Black Label Movement

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of a laser in the experiment described by the speaker?

options.label: C
options.text: To create a new state of matter

options.label: D
options.text: To trap atoms in a special bottle

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the new state of matter that atoms enter when cooled to absolute zero?

options.label: B
options.text: They flow with absolutely no viscosity or friction

options.label: A
options.text: Through a skeleton of rigid protein fibers

options.label: B
options.text: Through a network of flexible protein fibers

options.label: C
options.text: Through a system of pulleys and levers

title: How did English evolve? - Kate Gardoqui

multiple-choice.question: Who ruled the Celts in Britain in the year 400 C.E.?

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What language became the common language in Britain after the Roman withdrawal?

options.label: B

title: DNA: The book of you - Joe Hanson

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of cells in a human body?

options.label: B

title: The genius of Mendeleev’s periodic table

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with creating the periodic table?
What is the significance of the dash in Mendeleev's periodic table?

options.label: A
options.text: It represents an element that was already discovered but not well understood.

options.label: B
options.text: It represents an element that Mendeleev did not think was important.

options.label: C
options.text: It represents an element that Mendeleev predicted but had not yet been discovered.

options.label: D
options.text: It represents an element that was not a solid at room temperature.

What is the melting point of gallium in degrees Celsius?
